Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ecological Diversification and Molecular Evolution of Grasses (Poaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over 10,000 species of grasses are known to science. Grasses proliferated rapidly, obscuring their historical relationships. This project integrates three broad approaches in a study of grass diversification using contemporary methods to reconstruct the genealogy of the grasses. Next generation DNA sequencing methods will be used to determine complete chloroplast genomes and subregions of the nuclear genome from at least 100 species. Bioinformatics analyses will explore patterns and rates of DNA sequence evolution. Studies of development, especially in leaves, will be used to test whether particular adaptations are correlated with historical migrations into new habitats.

Grasses are of fundamental economic and ecological importance. Rice, wheat, maize and other cereals supply half of human dietary calories. Wild grasses predominate over 25% of Earth's terrestrial landscape. A better understanding of their relationships is fundamental to predicting the response of grasslands and cereal crops to environmental change. Analyses of sequence data will clarify relationships and have broad application in evolutionary studies. Ecological adaptations will be better understood when viewed in a developmental context. An image-rich web site will be established, with content in English and Spanish, with information on grass structure, classification, and evolution. The new framework of grass relationships and accompanying web resources will appeal to a broad range of users and promote international collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grasses include more than 11,000 species and constitute the plant family Poaceae. They provide more than 50% of human caloric intake in the form of corn, wheat, rice, oats, millet, sorghum, and barley. Other grass species are an important food source of grazers including cattle, sheep, and goats. Grass covers nearly 30% of Earth’s land surface and is the most economically important plant family. 

Understanding the relationship and similarities among grass genomes can inform the ongoing domestication, conservation, and utilization of grasses by humans, enabling us to more efficiently adapt our food production and habitat preservation systems in the face of climate change and population growth. The genome data collected can be used to better understand mutation in grass plastome DNA and provide an empirical template upon which future DNA analysis models and software can be based.

This project was a collaborative effort that advanced our understanding of grass evolution, anatomy, and genetics. Its specific findings include an improved resolution of genetic relationships among grass lineages, an advanced leaf analysis that helps describe and date the historical expansion of grasses into open habitats, and a biologically realistic alignment of 18 complete grass plastome sequences that accounts for all mutation types and frequencies.

Broader impacts of the work include a greatly increased (200+) addition of grass chloroplast genome sequences and several transcriptomes to public databases, a unique and important slide repository of grass leaf anatomy, and new tools for bioinformaticians, mathematicians, and computational scientists seeking to improve DNA alignment and analysis methods. Our phylogenetic trees of grass relationships have widespread applications in the agricultural and environmental sciences. The event-based genome alignment, the first of its kind, is an essential benchmark for bioinformaticians who seek to develop and test predictive models of insertion and deletion events in DNA.

To date, the project has produced more than 20 peer-reviewed scientific publications, with further papers in development. Several graduate, undergraduate, and high school students were trained in bioinformatic, scientific, and presentation skills. The project has connected more than a dozen countries in new research initiatives involving grasses, genomics, sequence alignment, and mathematical modeling of biological evolution.
